snippet: Fifty years after the Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright, the promise of legal representation for all is not fully realized.
abstract: Promise of legal representation for poor remains unfulfilled nearly 50 years after Supreme Court ruled that all defendants have constitutional right to lawyer; many states do not have resources to provide public defenders in all criminal cases, and Legal Services Corporation, Congressionally financed organization that provides legal aid in civil matters, calculates that 80 percent of legal needs of poor go unmet.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after the Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright, the promise of legal representation for all is not fully realized.

headline.seo: Right to a Lawyer Often Eludes the Poor
headline.main: Right to Lawyer Can Be Empty Promise for Poor
headline.print_headline: Right to Lawyer Can Be Empty Promise for Poor
